title: Huge fireball turns night into day as it streaks through sky over China

An enormous meteorite has been caught on camera streaking through the skies over northeast China.

The dazzling fireball appeared on Friday at around 00:16 CST, and was so bright that it turned the night into day, according to CCTV .

Surveillance cameras in the city of Songyuan were there to capture footage of the fireball, which was also seen by several surprised residents.

Thankfully, the video appears to show the meteorite burning up in the sky, indicating that only small bits of debris were likely to have reached the ground.

(Image: Live Science)

According to CCTV, the footage is now being analysed by experts from the Purple Mountain Observer of the Chinese Academy of Sciences .

When space rocks enter Earth’s atmosphere at high speed they burn up, making them glow brightly in the sky.

NASA explained: “When debris enters the Earth's atmosphere, friction between the debris and atmospheric gases heats it to the point that it glows and becomes visible to our eyes.

(Image: Live Science)

(Image: Live Science)

“This streak of light in the sky is known as a meteor. Most meteors glow for only a few seconds prior to burning up before hitting the Earth's surface.”

The sighting comes just days before one of the most beautiful meteor showers of the year - the Orionid meteor shower.

The spectacular event will take place between 2 October and 7 November this year.

However, the best time to see it will be at the peak, on 21 and 22 October, when you will be able to see 10 to 20 meteors per hour in a moonless sky.
